Description.TranslatedText: A unique identifier for a study sponsor. An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation and management of a clinical trial, although may or may not be the main funding organization. If there is also a secondary sponsor, this entity would be considered the primary sponsor. A corporation or agency whose employees conduct the investigation is considered a sponsor and the employees are considered investigators.
Unique identifier for a study.
Unique identifier for the study site; however, SITEID is also unique within a submission.
Subject identifier for the study.
Unique subject identifier within a submission.
Investigator identifier.
Visit Name / Visit Number.
Date and time the visit took place (or started).
Date the visit took place (or started).
End Date of the Visit
Time the visit took place (or started).
General prompt question regarding whether or not any AEs were experienced during the study. This provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.
A sponsor-defined identifier that can be used for pre-printed numbers on the CRF.
Verbatim (i.e., investigator-reported term) description of the adverse event.
Used when the occurrence of a specific adverse event is solicited to indicate whether or not (N/Y) the event (AETERM) occurred.
Date and Time when the adverse event started.
Date when the adverse event started.
Time when the adverse event started.
Date and time when the adverse event resolved.
Date when the adverse event resolved.
Time when the adverse event resolved.
Indicates AE is ongoing when no End Date is provided.
Description of the severity of the adverse event.
Description of the toxicity grade of the adverse event.
Indicates whether or not the adverse event is determined to be “serious” based on what is defined in the protocol.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event was associated with a congenital anomaly or birth defect.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event was associated with a persistent or significant disability or incapacity.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event resulted in death.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event resulted in an initial or prolonged hospitalization for the subject.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event was life threatening.
Indicates if a “serious” adverse event is associated with other serious or important medical events.
Indication of whether the study treatment had a causal effect on the adverse event, as reported by the clinician/investigator.
Changes made to the study treatment in response to the adverse event.
Describes Other Action(s) taken in response to the adverse event that are unrelated to study treatment dose changes.
Description of the subject’s status associated with an event.
Indication of whether the adverse event caused the subject to discontinue from the study.
General prompt question to aid in monitoring and data cleaning.
A sponsor-defined identifier which can be used for pre-printed numbers on the CRF.
Verbatim drug name or therapy (include only therapies with data collection characteristics similar medications).

Used when the occurrence of a specific medication or treatment is solicited to indicate whether or not (N/Y) the treatment or medication (CMTRT) was taken or given.
This field can be used for either prior or concomitant medication / treatments.
{NY} (See Section 2.2.)
Medication Ingredients.

The reason for administration of a concomitant (non-study) medication. (e.g., Nausea, Hypertension) This is not the pharmacological/ therapeutic classification of an agent (e.g., antibiotic, analgesic, etc.), but the reason for its administration to the subject.
Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this medication.
Identifier for the medical history condition that is the indication for this medication.
The dose of medication taken per administration.
The dose of medication taken per administration.
Total daily dose taken.
Name of the pharmaceutical dosage form (e.g., TABLET CAPSULE, SYRUP) of delivery for the drug.
How often the medication was taken (e.g., BID, PRN).
Identifies the route of administration of the drug.
Date and Time when the medication was first taken.
Date when the medication was first taken.
Time the medication was started.
To determine if medications were taken prior to study start.
Date and time that the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy.
Date that the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy.
Time when the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy.
Indicates medication or therapy is ongoing when no End Date is provided.
A subject’s date and time of birth.
A subject’s date of birth (with or without the time of birth). The complete Date of Birth is made from the temporal components of Birth Year, Birth Month, Birth Day and Birth Time.
Year of the subject’s birth.
Text value for the month of the subject’s birth.
Numeric day of the month of the subject’s birth.
Time of subject’s birth.
Numeric age of subject.
Numeric age of subject.

Those units of time that are routinely used to express the age of a person. (NCI)
{AGEU} (See Section 2.2.)
Date of collection.

The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female (NCI – CDISC Definition). {SEX} (See Section 2.2.)

A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease (NCI – CDISC Definition). {ETHNIC} (See Section 2.2.)

An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control).
{RACE} (See Section 2.2.)
A free-text field to be used when none of the pre-printed values for RACE are applicable or if another, unprinted selection needs to be added to those pre-printed values.

An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control).
{RACE} (See Section 2.2.)

An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control).
{RACE} (See Section 2.2.)

An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control).
{RACE} (See Section 2.2.)
